awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer to Enhance Undergraduate Research and Teaching at a Primarily Undergraduate Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Kevin Minbiole from Villanova University and colleagues Robert Giuliano, Deanna Zubris, Aimee Eggler and Thomas Umile Gwynedd from Mercy College have acquired a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as allow study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The instrument positively impacts several institutions that participate in the Southeastern Pennsylvania Consortium for Higher Education. Well-documented utilization in classroom activities is also positive. Inclusion of a co-PI from another institution (Mercy College) is a demonstration of the commitment to partner with other institutions.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  It especially aids in the identification of natural product structures and the rapid and in-depth structural characterization of amphiphiles that lead to improved structure-activity. The instrument is also used to fully characterize 4-amino sugars found in antibiotics and cell-surface glycans and glycosyl cyanides found in fungal toxins as well as in the confirmation of the structure of diplopyrone. In addition, it is essential for the characterization of synthetic analogues of marine sponge-derived Nrf2 activators and for the comprehensive characterization of structure changes in the oxidizable diphenols in phosphate buffered saline. The spectrometer benefits the determination of purity of trace amounts of purchased natural products and the characterization of paramagnetic iron complexes (catalysts) for atom transfer radical polymerization and mechanistic evaluation. It is also essential for the characterization of polymers containing multi-cationic quaternary ammonium compounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

por.por_cntn:
Oftentimes the greatest challenge of chemical research is the determination of the structure of compounds - molecules that have been built in the lab or isolated from Nature. And there is no better chemical instrument to determine molecular structure than a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer.  The main goal of this NSF grant has been to acquire, install, and utilize a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer for Villanova University.  Specifically, MRI funding was obtained to purchase a JEOL JNM-ECZR 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer to enable research and training programs encompassing biochemistry and organic, medicinal, organometallic, polymer, and natural product chemistry.

The instrument supports high-level, student-driven research in the laboratories of not only the grant's five principal investigators, but also in the labs of other chemists and scientists at Villanova, as well as those at a nearby consortium of undergraduate institutions (SEPCHE). This has led to a wide variety of publications, on topics spanning the development of novel antiseptics, light-harvesting compounds for use in alternative energy development, novel catalysts for environmentally-friendly polymer production, and the development of novel herbicides.

This instrument provides hands-on training for a wide variety of Villanova students. In most semesters, we have 30-45 undergraduates doing research in our department, and at least half of those used the new spectrometer for molecular characterization. In summer 2021, 37 undergraduates did a full summer of research, heavily relying on the NMR spectrometer. A similar fraction of the ~20 masters students in our department heavily use this instrument.

In the context of laboratory courses, we have been able to get our entire class (16-20 students annually) of sophomore chemistry majors comfortable with the instrument through Organic Chemistry Laboratory I and II. The NMR is also used extensively in our Instrumental Analysis course, in Biophysical Chemistry, and other courses.

The NMR supported by this NSF-MRI grant has already become the centerpiece of a larger Instrument Suite, which supports a wide variety of molecular characterization instrumentation. This Instrument Suite is now a gem of Villanova's campus; a single room boasts two high field NMR spectrometers with autosamplers, an x-ray diffractometer, and a new accurate mass liquid chromatograph mass spectrometer (LCMS). Simply put, this grant-supported NMR spectrometer is the centerpiece of a game-changing center for Villanova's research enterprise moving forward.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2021
Modified by: Kevin P Minbiole
